* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable): `$ jupyter labextension list`
```
        @jupyter-widgets/jupyterlab-manager v2.0.0  enabled  OK
        qgrid2 v1.1.3  enabled  OK
```
### Description of Issue

Pandas DataFrames containing columns with datetime dtype are no longer displayed by qgrid in JupyterLab 2.1.2, i.e., nothing appears in the cell output, and no error message is displayed.

### Reproduction Steps

1. After installing JupyterLab 2.1.2, qgrid 1.3.1, and the required JupyterLab extensions, attempt to run the following code in a new notebook:
```python
import datetime
import pandas as pd
import qgrid

df = pd.DataFrame({'a': [datetime.datetime(2020,1,1,10,1), datetime.datetime(2020,1,1,11)]})
qgrid.show_grid(df)
```
2. Nothing will be displayed in the cell output.
3. If the DataFrame is modified to contain a mix of datetime and non-datetime
values, the DataFrame will be displayed normally.
4. Repeat the above with JupyterLab 2.1.0; the qgrid widget will be displayed normally.

### What steps have you taken to resolve this already?

Revert to JupyterLab 2.1.0.

items.title: Javascript inconsistent between PyPI and npm/unpkg
items.body:
### Environment

* Operating System: Ubuntu
* Python Version: 3.7.4
* How did you install Qgrid: pip
* Python packages: qgrid 1.2.0, notebook 6.0.3, voila 0.1.20
* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable): N/A

### Description of Issue

Qgrid widget does not display in Voila in certain scenarios.  Please see ongoing discussion at https://github.com/voila-dashboards/voila/issues/72.  A couple people identified a workaround where they changed the first line of `qgrid/index.js` from this (which is what you get from PyPI):

`define(["@jupyter-widgets/base","base/js/dialog"], ...`

to this (which is what you get from [unpkg.com](https://unpkg.com/qgrid@1.1.1/dist/index.js)):

`define(["@jupyter-widgets/base"], ...`

### Reproduction Steps

1. Install voila and qgrid and enable extensions
2. Turn off your internet to prevent Voila's fallback to unpkg.com
3. Qgrid widget will not display

### What steps have you taken to resolve this already?

See [my recent comment](https://github.com/voila-dashboards/voila/issues/72#issuecomment-583617677) in the Voila thread.

### Anything else?

We love qgrid but would prefer to avoid patching it! :)

notebook=5.6.0

### Description of Issue

* What did you expect to happen?
sort columns, scroll to see all rows of a df 
* What happened instead?
In qgrid=1.1.0 and 1.1.1 only 100 rows are visible, scrolling down beyond 100 rows shows empty rows.

The UI hangs for both sorting and filtering (wheel keeps running) irrespective of the number of rows in the df.

### Reproduction Steps
import qgrid
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.rand(200, 10))
dd = qgrid.QgridWidget(df=df)
dd

### What steps have you taken to resolve this already?
Reverted to qgrid=1.0.5, where it behaves as expected.

items.title: Cannot set Categorical columns containing quotes
items.body:
### Environment

* Operating System: Linux
* Python Version: 3.6.5
* How did you install Qgrid: `pip`
* Python packages: 
```
qgrid==1.0.5
notebook==5.3.0
jupyterlab==0.32.1
```
* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable): `$ jupyter labextension list`
```
@jupyter-widgets/jupyterlab-manager
        @jupyter-widgets/jupyterlab-manager v0.35.0  enabled  OK
qgrid
        qgrid v1.0.5  enabled  OK
```

### Description of Issue

* What did you expect to happen?

Being able to select a categorical data containing arbitrary text, including quotes. In particular, I was expecting to set a category item among `{"ConL1", "ConL2", "ConL3", "ConLS", "ConLS'"}.

* What happened instead?

1. When I encountered this bug for the first time, I got an error popup, and the following traceback in the server log:
```python
[IPKernelApp] ERROR | Error occurred while attempting to edit the DataFrame. Check the notebook server logs for more information.
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/home/althonos/.local/lib/python3.6/site-packages/qgrid/grid.py", line 1224, in _handle_qgrid_msg_helper
    self._df.loc[location] = val_to_set
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py", line 189, in __setitem__
    self._setitem_with_indexer(indexer, value)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py", line 615, in _setitem_with_indexer
    setter(item, value)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/indexing.py", line 539, in setter
    s._data = s._data.setitem(indexer=pi, value=v)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/internals.py", line 3693, in setitem
    return self.apply('setitem', **kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/internals.py", line 3581, in apply
    applied = getattr(b, f)(**kwargs)
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/internals.py", line 1934, in setitem
    self.values[indexer] = value
  File "/usr/lib/python3.6/site-packages/pandas/core/arrays/categorical.py", line 1982, in __setitem__
    raise ValueError("Cannot setitem on a Categorical with a new "
ValueError: Cannot setitem on a Categorical with a new category, set the categories first
```

2. When trying to come with a reproducible test case, I could only reach a point where the update would simply not happen, but no error would be raised.

### Reproduction Steps

1. Create a notebook with the following cell:
```python
import qgrid
import pandas

df = pandas.DataFrame({'test': pandas.Categorical(['', ''], categories={'', "Hi", "'Hello'"})})
qgrid.QGridWidget(df=df, show_toolbar=True)
```
2. Try to set the value of the `test` column to `'Hello'`: nothing is updated (the cell stays empty).

items.title: Can't update _selected_rows from python
items.body:
I'm wondering how to change the selected rows from Python. I couldn't figure out a way to propagate the `._selected_rows` attribute to the browser and have it update the table styling.

I want to synchronize the index of the selected row in a qgrid table with a Holoviews Stream. Right now I have the qgrid->Stream direction working (i.e., click on a row, and it updates the stream), but I'd like the reverse as well (i.e., whenever the stream updates, I want the highlighted row to change in the browser).

On Python 3.6.5, qgrid from git master, latest jupyterlab via pip.

### Description of Issue
I'm displaying a dataframe, and trying to edit it. I get the following error:

### Reproduction Steps
In a notebook:
```
data = [[0, 28108, 'blah1', 'asd', 6, 0.6093999743461609, True],

grid
```

Then, try editing any of the cells. In Jupyterlab, I get a popup: `Error occurred while attempting to edit the DataFrame. Check the notebook server logs for more information.`. In the console:

items.title: Provide edit cell location after editing.
items.body:
Currently one can observe that the dataframe has been edited by using:

```
def func(change):
    print(change)

q_gridwidget = qgrid.QgridWidget(df)
q_gridwidget.observe(func, '_df')
```

However, the function does not know the location (index/col) of the cell that was edited. This is known in the [code](https://github.com/quantopian/qgrid/blob/master/qgrid/grid.py#L912). Could the [_trigger_df_change_event](https://github.com/quantopian/qgrid/blob/master/qgrid/grid.py#L966) be sent that location (via keyword args) to include in the `Bunch` returned by that method?

I'm willing to submit a PR if that helps. My alternative is to subclass QGridWidget, but that seems a bit extreme.

items.title: Widget not shown with Jupyter Lab 0.31.32 and qgrid 1.0.2
items.body:
### Environment

* Operating System: **Windows 10 64bit**
* Python Version: **Python 3.6.4 :: Anaconda custom (64-bit)**
* How did you install Qgrid: **conda**
* Python packages:
  - ...
  - jupyterlab                **0.31.12**                  py36_0
  - notebook                  **5.0.0**            py36hd9fbf6f_2
  - qgrid                     **1.0.2**                    py36_1
  - ...
* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable): -

### Description of Issue

* What did you expect to happen?
I expected the table widget to be shown on my notebook.
* What happened instead?
Text `A Jupyter Widget` gets displayed instead.

### Reproduction Steps

1. I installed qgrid and its lab-extension:
    ```Bash
    $ conda install qgrid
    $ jupyter labextension install qgrid
    ```

2. Imported a dataset, imported it into a DataFrame with Pandas, then took a subset of it:
    ```python
    from sklearn.datasets import load_boston
    import pandas as pd
    boston = load_boston()
    df = pd.DataFrame(boston['data'], columns=boston['feature_names'])
    hdf = df[:20]
    ```
2. Imported qgrid and used to display a `df` qgrid:
    ```python
    import qgrid
    qgrid.show_grid(hdf)
    ```

### What steps have you taken to resolve this already?
Checked whether qgrid version and qgrid notebook extension version were the same.  
Tried with a traditional Jupyter notebook in the same environment and with the same code and it works.  


### Anything else?

No.

Update grid ```python tmp = qgrid_widget.df.copy() tmp.loc[:,'B'] = tmp.loc[:,'B'] * 2 qgrid_widget.df = tmp ``` ### What steps have you taken to resolve this already? Be satisfied with the awesome package despite minor flaws and raise an issue about them :) ### Anything else? Thanks for the super cool widget! I can't believe I didn't know about this before! Oliver

[LibraryList.txt](https://github.com/quantopian/qgrid/files/1918787/LibraryList.txt)

* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable): `$ jupyter labextension list`

### Description of Issue
Hi,
I`m loading a dataframe into qgrid:

`qgrid_widget = qgrid.QgridWidget(df=dfCRD)`
`qgrid_widget`

dfCRD has 24 columns which are stacked and unreadable.

* What did you expect to happen?

Wanted columns to have  widths allowing to see the names. Thus qgrid should be scrollable horizonally. 

* What happened instead?
dfCRD has 24 columns which are stacked and unreadable.
### Reproduction Steps

Clean Jupytelab notebook

Loading dfCRD dataframe with cx_oracle
3.
`qgrid_widget = qgrid.QgridWidget(df=dfCRD)`
`qgrid_widget`

`qgrid_widget = qgrid.QgridWidget(df=dfCRD, show_toolbar=True, options={'forceFitColumns': False, 'defaultColumnWidth': 200
})`
`qgrid_widget`

The result is the same.

items.title: Error displaying widget in beta Jupyterlab (v0.31)
items.body:
### Environment

* Operating System: Windows 10
* Python Version: `Python 3.6.2` Anaconda
* How did you install Qgrid: `pip`
* Python packages: 
`qgrid 1.0.0`,
 `notebook 5.0.0`,
 `jupyterlab 0.31.10`
* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable):
 `@jupyter-widgets/jupyterlab-manager v0.33.2`
`qgrid v1.0.1`

### Description of Issue

Attempting to use `qgrid` within the recent beta release of `jupyterlab`.  Instead of seeing the interactive data frame, I get an error message **Error displaying widget**.  I tested creating another `ipywidgets` slider widget with success.  See the image attached below.

 
![jlab_issue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/8412364/36907173-8574fe48-1dfd-11e8-96b8-c14545f25b49.png)


### Reproduction Steps
```
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd
import qgrid as q

df = pd.DataFrame(np.random.random((6,6)))

w = q.show_grid(df)

w
```

items.title: Observing "_df" does not trigger when a cell is changed
items.body:
Example:
`qgrid_widget.observe(func, names=['_df'])`
will not trigger on a 'cell_change' (i.e. double clicking a cell and changing the value).

Hack that works ('touch'):
`df = self._df.copy(); self._df = df`

items.title: qgrid is not correctly resizing when it is unhidden inside of an accordion widget
items.body:
When placing a qgrid inside of an Accordion widget which is not initially shown, qgrid columns are not properly resized when the qgrid accordion tab is selected. This issue most likely has to do with qgrid not resizing when its state is changed from hidden to visible. The columns are correctly resized by resizing the window or alternatively resetting the qgrid df.


Example. 
grid = show_grid(df)
accordion= Accordion(children=[grid])
accordion.selected_index = None

when you click the accordion tab, qgrid columns will be sized incorrectly.

If I resize the window, or reset qgrid.df the columns are correctly set again.

grid.df = grid.df

items.title: ipywidgets stop working after enabling qgrid
items.body:
### Environment

* Operating System: OSX
* Python Version: 3.6
* How did you install Qgrid: pip
* Python packages: notebook 5.2.2, jupyterlab 0.31.0, qgrid 1.0.0, ipywidgets 7.1.0
* Jupyter lab packages (if applicable): @jupyter-widgets/jupyterlab-manager v0.33.0, qgrid v1.0.0

### Description of Issue

ipywidgets fail to render in JupyterLab after installing/enabling the qgrid Lab extension.

### Reproduction Steps

1. Open a notebook in jupyterlab.
2. `import qgrid; qgrid.show_grid(a_df)`
3. Grid appears (but with some errors in the JS console)
4. `import ipywidgets; ipywidgets.Button(description="test")`
5. "Error displaying widget` appears in the notebook
6. Stop lab, run `jupyter labextension disable qgrid`, restart lab
7. Try the ipywidgets test again
8. Button appears as expected

### What steps have you taken to resolve this already?

> Please Note: Jupyterlab support has been tested with jupyterlab 0.30.5 and jupyterlab-manager 0.31.3, so if you're having trouble, try installing those versions. Feel free to file an issue if you find that qgrid isn't working with a newer version of either dependency.

I can fallback on older versions of lab and widgets-manager. I'm opening this ticket to raise awareness about a likely problem with the latest versions.

```
import numpy as np

qgrid_widget
```

```
import pandas

qgrid.set_defaults(grid_options={
            'fullWidthRows': True,
            'syncColumnCellResize': True,
```

```
import pandas
df=pandas.DataFrame({"mobs":[1,2,3,4]})
import qgrid
qgrid.set_defaults(grid_options=None)
qgrid.show_grid(df)
```

items.title: qgrid throws exception and locks up widget when sorting columns with mixed datatypes
items.body:
When sorting a column of a DataFrame with mixed datatypes, the following exception is raised by pandas:

```
[IPKernelApp] ERROR | '>' not supported between instances of 'float' and 'str'
[IPKernelApp] ERROR | Unhandled exception while handling msg
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "C:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\qgrid\grid.py", line 743, in _handle_qgrid_msg
    self._handle_qgrid_msg_helper(content)
  File "C:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\qgrid\grid.py", line 805, in _handle_qgrid_msg_helper
    self._update_sort()
  File "C:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\qgrid\grid.py", line 491, in _update_sort
    inplace=True
  File "C:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\frame.py", line 3201, in sort_values
    na_position=na_position)
  File "C:\Anaconda3\lib\site-packages\pandas\core\sorting.py", line 247, in nargsort
    indexer = non_nan_idx[non_nans.argsort(kind=kind)]
TypeError: '>' not supported between instances of 'float' and 'str'
```

This is the expected behavior from pandas, but qgrid should prevent this from locking up the widget.

Here is a reproducible example:

```
import pandas as pd
import qgrid
df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [1.2, 'xy', 4]})
qgrid_widget = qgrid.QgridWidget(df=df, show_toolbar=True)
qgrid_widget
```

Clicking on the header of column 'A' or attempting to resize the column will raise the exception.

items.title: Handle new Interval type
items.body:
Pandas 0.20.0 introduced [Interval type](http://pandas.pydata.org/pandas-docs/stable/whatsnew.html#whatsnew-0200-enhancements-intervalindex). Currently qgrid raises 'TypeError' when handling it.

Here's an example code to reproduce the problem:
```python
import numpy as np
import pandas as pd

td = np.cumsum(np.random.randint(1, 15*60, 1000))
start = pd.Timestamp('2017-04-17')
df = pd.DataFrame(
    [(start + pd.Timedelta(seconds=d)) for d in td],
    columns=['time'])

freq = '15Min'
start = df['time'].min().floor(freq)
end = df['time'].max().ceil(freq)
bins = pd.date_range(start, end, freq=freq)

df['time_bin'] = pd.cut(df['time'], bins)

import qgrid
qgrid.show_grid(df)
```

items.title: qgrid requires ipywidgets-4.1.1
items.body: I'm putting this here both as an issue for potential fixing, and a warning to others who might burn a whole day trying to debug this.  qgrid will _not_ work with version 5+ of ipywidgets.  There has been significant code refactoring, and the relevant javascript that's used by qgrid is no longer where expected.  I've spent a little time looking into what it would take to update qgrid to work with ipywidgets 5+, but am not familiar enough with the codebases to have a good feel for how difficult the task will be.

items.title: update version on pypi
items.body: The version currently available on pypi force-downgrades several packages.  It would be nice to update to the current version on pypi, which has fixed requirements.txt, so this doesn't happen anymore.

items.title: Making edits permanent
items.body:
How to make edits permanent?   The demo notebook suggests a grid is editable by default, and that the dataframe is updated. 

   I may be missing something very obvious but I can't seem to make my edits to a dataframe permanent using qgrid . I'm basically following he demo notebook. The dataframe displays nicely when I call 

```
qgrid.show_grid(df)
```

I can click on cells to change values.  Those new values continue to display in that grid as I move around.  However when I run the code to display the same dataframe again from the same cell for from a cell lower down in my notebook, all my edits appear to be lost. I just see the content of the original dataframe.  

Is there some setting I need to change?  The [qgrid documentation](http://qgrid.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) states these settings are passed to slickgrid

```
{
    'fullWidthRows': True,
    'syncColumnCellResize': True,
    'forceFitColumns': True,
    'rowHeight': 28,
    'enableColumnReorder': False,
    'enableTextSelectionOnCells': True,
    'editable': True,
    'autoEdit': False
}
```

Should any of these be different?

items.title: Autofilter Scroll
items.body: Is it possible to scroll within the autofilter selection page?  i.e. when i select the autofilter, only a subset of the items in the column are listed and there does not appear to be a way to scroll within that list.

items.title: Jupyter kernel crashes
items.body:
I am using Python 2.7.8 and Jupyter 4.0.6 on CENTOS 6. I use the following code to render qgrid.
"import qgrid
qgrid.show_grid(df)"

In some cases it works with no issue.  Although with wider df's I get a "kernel restarting" error on Jupyter which states "The kernel appears to have died. It will restart automatically". This is the only time I've had this occur on Jupyter (when I use qgrid).
I was able to fix this by changing my PANDAS dataframe column types FROM 'category'. It seems qgrid crashes when trying to render PANDAS 'category' data types?

Further, with PANDAS datetime column types, it does not display the 'time' part of the field.

items.title: Adding and Removing Rows does not work
items.body:
The following code seems to throw some javascript errors when I click on Add/Remove Rows:
Selection and Editing still seem to work fine.

This is using python 2.7, IPython 4.1.1 and master branch of qgrid.

```
import qgrid
import IPython
print IPython.__version__

import pandas
import numpy as np

res = pandas.DataFrame(np.arange(20).reshape(10,2))
```

items.title: Tables selectively not rendering
items.body:
Howdy, 
I have a notebook where the following correctly displays a table:

```
df = pd.DataFrame([1,2,3,4])
qgrid.show_grid(df)
```

However, when I try to display a denser dataframe in the same notebook, the output shows, but is removed on page refresh, while the above continues to display correctly. Is there some sort of limit to how big the dataframe can be? Any other potential cause for this? I can't release the dataset that's causing this. Some ideas for possible causes would be great so I can make a reproducible case. 

Edit: was able to repro the issue by repeatedly displaying a dataframe with of dimensions around 15x100. 3 times seems to do the trick to cause failure.
Seems like it was dataframe size related after all:

items.title: Possible install issue with an existing Anaconda environment
items.body:
Hello, this is a partial bug message, I figured it was worth filing in case others have a similar issue. I have an existing Python 3.4 Anaconda environment called "scratch" (I use it for all side projects). It has numpy, pandas, IPython Notebook and lots more.

I already had a version of qgrid from at least 6 months back, installed back in the mists of time.

I just tried `pip install -U git+https://github.com/quantopian/qgrid` (adding `-U` to your install notes) and it had a crack at uninstalling my Anaconda-provided numpy+pandas+notebook. I killed it and thankfully it hadn't nuked my environment.

I cloned your repo locally and edited `setup.py` to remove the `install_requires` dependencies, then ran `python setup.py install` and I have the latest version. I'm not sure what happened but I figure it is worth noting (but feel free to close/delete if this isn't a helpful-enough bug report!).

items.title: Release show_toolbar
items.body: As far as I can see, the `show_toolbar` option isn't available on the latest released version. Could you do another release?
